comment: no gender / class

It is noted that in all adjectives that have a class marker, there is a class suffix, and in some, a class prefix is also present. However, it is also said that the class suffix is omitted in the majority of cases in NPs (so adjectives modifying a noun are described as agreeing in class (p. 66), but with the suffix class marker omitted (in most cases, p. 40)). I am not sure how to best describe this. Also value6: it is stated that one group of adjectives lacks a class marker, the remaining adjectives have class markers.

It is stated that class markers may be present "in the anlaut, auslaut, or both", but after that, all adjectives are classified into"auslaut only" & "anlaut & auslaut" & "no class marker". The "auslaut only" strategy is limited to 6 adjectives. Adjectives with no class marker are described as a type of adjective that also exists, with some examples given. I am not sure if it would be right to assume this means they are less common than "anlaut & auslaut" adjectives.
Value6: adjectives may have a class agreement prefix, but many do not. I think this is "no information" as to which of these is more common
Adjectives with "class markers in the middle" attested (infix?). Value6 "no information" is similar to the case above: "many adjectives have class markers, many do not".

Adjective with "class marker in the middle" attested (infix?). Value6: it is said that the majority of adjectives do not show class agreement; among those that do, class prefixes are the most common strategy.

Value6: adjectives without a class marker are described as a small class (p. 113); the suffix strategy appears to be the default (kibrik1977). Prefix + suffix adjectives are not mentioned in (kibrik1977) but are mentioned in (mikailov1967) as a small class.
no gender / class
no gender / class
"Most common strategy"/Value6 information from (alexeyevverheesdraft2020).
Value6: (vandenberg2001) says very few adjectives show class agreement. Also see comment on value1
Leaving the row for Chirag empty for now :(
Value6: presumably, as it is the only strategy referenced

I am not sure I can safely make any claims here. It is said that adjectives may show class agreement (but not all do) on p. 106, but the only example of an adjective with a class marker I found was among examples of substantivized adjectives (p. 114). Very little information is given on class agreement in adjectives (or I cannot find it).

The attested class markers are prefixes (no other ones are given), they occur on adjectives in NPs, but the authors argue this isn’t actually the adjective agreeing with the head noun (this is mentioned and briefly discussed on the pages that i cite, see also pp. 191-199). I do not know if this is actually relevant for the purposes of my table, and have filled this row in from the perspective that it isn’t. Value6: it is mentioned that “some” (некоторые; некоторое количество) adjectives have a class marker; I am hesitant to draw any conclusions from this.
no gender / class

Very interesting information on groups of adjectives: over 60% of adjectives show class agreement; more than half of those adjectives are loan words from Avar, which show suffixal class markers; all adjectives of Khwarshi origin that show class agreement, on the other hand, have class prefixes. Almost all of the adjectives that do not show class agreement are of Khwarshi origin. I left Value6 as "no information" as it is not clear whether the number of adjectives with class suffixes ("over half" of "over 60%", so 30-40%) is larger or smaller than the number of adjectives with no class agreement (also 30-40%)
no gender/class

Infix attested. Also prefix + infix? I would much prefer if someone double-checked that I understand the sources correctly... Value6: adjectives with a class marker of some sort about as common as adjectives without (zhirkov1955). I am not sure how to assign a value to this
no gender/class
no gender/class
The majority of adjectives do not have class markers; a few do, and it looks like infixation to me.

It is said (in (ibragimov1978)) that differences between Myukhrek & Mukhad in this respect are insignificant, but also, in discussing an unrelated trait of the adjective ‘good’ when substantivized, it is shown having a class prefix. I checked the Atlas of Rutul dialects & there it says that there is no agreement in the adjective 'good'. I filled this in the same way as Mukhad for now. I do not know how to indicate the particular page of the Atlas of Rutul dialects, but this one: https://lingconlab.github.io/rutul_dialectology/060_Gender_agreement_in_the_adjective_%E2%80%9Cgood%E2%80%9D.html
The same pattern as in Mukhad.

In (ibragimov1978),  1) "prefix-infix class agreement" (the examples given seem to show either one or the other; no details are given) & 2) attributive suffixes that take different forms for classes 1-3 vs 4, like in Tsakhur (see my description of Tsakhur below) are described. “Ixrek Authier” (not in biblib?) seems to indicate that the attributive suffix always shows agreement (...takes different forms for classes 1-3 vs 4), & in some adjectives there is also a class prefix. Infixation is not mentioned.

“послекорневое классовое согласование” (i.e., suffix?) in one adjective (also attested in the Atlas of Rutul dialects); but also the same attributive suffix pattern as in Ikhrek. So like in Tsakhur, a combination of a suffixal class marker & this attributive suffix showing agreement is possible.

All adjectives except two do not show class agreement in NPs. ((magometov1965, p. 152-155), states that there is dialect variation: in some idioms, only one of these two shows class agreement, and in some, both)
no gender/class

Class marker prefixes and suffixes (not both at the same time); also attributive suffixes that also show class agreement (take different forms for classes 1-3 vs 4 in the singular). Attributive suffixes can co-occur with class marker prefixes and suffixes. Also, it is stated that this works the same in Gel'mets, though no illustrations are given (so I left this as a comment).
Value6: "a few adjectives agree for gender-number"
no gender/class
